Enhanced oxygen removal ability of sulfur-doped Ru/TiO2 catalyst in low-temperature hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol Hyungjoo Kim Conceptualization Methodology Formal analysis Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Visualization a Seungdo Yang Validation Writing – original draft a Yong Hyun Lim Validation Writing – original draft a Jae Hyun Park Validation Writing – original draft a Jeong-Myeong Ha Project administration Funding acquisition b Do Heui Kim Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Supervision a ⁎ a School of Chemical and Biological Engineering, and Institute of Chemical Process, Seoul National University, 1, Gwanak-ro, Gwanak-gu, Seoul 08826, Republic of Korea School of Chemical and Biological Engineering, and Institute of Chemical Process, Seoul National University 1, Gwanak-ro Gwanak-gu Seoul 08826 Republic of Korea School of Chemical and Biological Engineering, and Institute of Chemical Process, Seoul National University, 1, Gwanak-ro, Gwanak-gu, Seoul, 08826, Republic of Korea b Clean Energy Research Center, Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST), Seoul 02792, Republic of Korea Clean Energy Research Center, Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST) Seoul 02792 Republic of Korea Clean Energy Research Center, Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST), Seoul 02792, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Hydrodeoxygenation of bio-oil to obtain oxygen-free hydrocarbon at low-temperature remains a substantial challenge to produce economically feasible biomass-derived fuel. Among the various Ru-loaded catalysts, Ru/DT-51, a sulfate-containing anatase TiO2, showed prominent oxygen removal attributed to the sulfur content of the catalysts. The introduction of sulfur on Ru/TiO2 resulted in lower conversion of guaiacol, although the degree of oxygen removal obtained at 100% conversion was significantly enhanced, with 50% even at mild reaction temperature of 100 °C. The introduction of sulfur modified the distribution of exposed Ru species by selectively covering Ru in the form of sulfide, which was confirmed through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), CO chemisorption, CO diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (CO-DRIFT), and temperature-programmed-desorption of ammonia coupled with a mass detector (NH3-TPD-MS). By introducing sulfur to Ru/TiO2, the product selectivity in guaiacol HDO was regulated to enhance the oxygen removal even at a low temperature of 100 °C. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Low temperature Guaiacol Ru/TiO2 Sulfur doping Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the increasing greenhouse gas emissions owing to the usage of hydrocarbon-based energy resources, the rapid increase in the global temperature has resulted in extreme climate changes. Consequently, worldwide interest to alleviate the extreme climate changes for sustainable development has led to many international commitments, including “net zero emission by 2050”, thus accelerating the demand for advanced green technologies to mitigate CO2 emissions and the usage of conventional fossil-based energy resources [1]. Among them, lignin-based pyrolysis oil has been in the limelight as a green alternative to replace fossil fuel [2,3]. However, direct usage of pyrolysis oil as a sustainable substitute for fossil-based resources has been limited by its high oxygen content, thus necessitating the oxygen removal process called hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) [2–4]. Lignin-derived pyrolysis oil is a mixture of various hydrocarbon oxygenates, with ca. 30% of phenolic contents. Guaiacol is a phenolic compound containing a methoxy group and a hydroxyl group, and it is extensively utilized as a representative phenolic model compound for HDO [5–9]. The reaction pathway of guaiacol HDO has been simplified in Scheme S1, which proceeds through various reaction intermediates following the combination of deoxygenation and hydrogenation reactions. Generally, the HDO of guaiacol is performed under severe reaction conditions (with high temperature and hydrogen pressure) to obtain oxygen-free hydrocarbons [6,8,10–13]. However, since the harsh reaction conditions increase the operating costs of the process and accelerate the catalyst deactivation, an advanced catalyst showing high oxygen removal ability under mild reaction conditions must be developed. To our best knowledge, only a few studies have been reported conducting HDO of phenolic compounds to obtain oxygen-free hydrocarbon at a low temperature of around 100 °C or below [14–17]. Dyson et al. reported the catalytic system of metal nanoparticles combined with Brønsted acidic ionic liquid (IL) producing cyclohexane from phenolic compounds under mild reaction conditions [14,17]. Pt/C combined with low-redox-potential polyoxometallate acid (H4SiW12O40) [16] and highly-dispersed Pd–Mo catalysts [15] have also been reported to possess high HDO activity under a low reaction temperature (around 110 °C or below) and low hydrogen pressure (ambient H2 pressure and 1 MPa, respectively). Although the above-mentioned catalytic system showed high HDO activity under mild reaction conditions (above 90% of oxygen removal), expensive noble metals (such as Pt and Pd), IL, and substantial homogeneous heteropoly acid were used in this case. Therefore, the development of a new catalytic system for low-temperature HDO utilizing cost-effective metal, which does not use expensive ionic liquids and homogeneous acids, is required to mitigate the economic and environmental liabilities. Ru is an extensively investigated metal for HDO catalysts due to its high hydrogenation and HDO activity, besides being economically more attractive compared to expensive noble metals, including Pt and Pd [18–20]. The catalytic activity of Ru-based catalysts could be modified by controlling various characteristics of the catalysts. Dispersion of Ru [21] or the acidic properties of the catalysts [22] could be altered by utilizing various support materials, which significantly affect the conversion and product selectivity. In addition to the support, surface modification by doping heteroatom has been widely utilized to improve the HDO activity and control product selectivity. Wang et al. reported the incorporation of Cl into Ru/TiO2 used in guaiacol HDO, which notably modified the electronic properties of Ru and Ti, resulting in the enhanced phenol selectivity in exchange for the decreased conversion of guaiacol with the increasing amount of Cl [23]. Reportedly, the activity of HDO catalysts can be enhanced through the introduction of various promoters, such as Re [24], Mo [25], and W [26]. In this study, to explore the catalysts with high HDO activity at low temperatures, Ru supported on commercially-available supports were synthesized. Consequently, high cyclohexane yield and oxygen removal were confirmed when Ru was supported on DT-51, which is a sulfate-containing commercial anatase TiO2. A systematic approach was applied to confirm the origin of high HDO activity at low temperature in Ru/DT-51, which confirmed that sulfur content contained in DT-51 was responsible for its superior catalytic activity. The reaction pathway of guaiacol HDO was proposed by conducting the reaction using various reaction intermediates as reactants, which confirmed negligible deoxygenation rates of aliphatic oxygenates at 100 °C while utilizing Ru/DT-51. To demonstrate the effect of the sulfur content, catalysts with various S/Ru ratios were synthesized, and 50% oxygen removal could be obtained for the reaction occurring at 100 °C for 4 h under 10 bar H2. XPS, CO chemisorption, CO DRIFT, NH3–TPD–MS, and isothermal NH3 adsorption/desorption experiments were conducted to identify the effect of S doping on Ru/TiO2, which confirmed that S doping selectively concealed specific Ru sites, resulting in the modified distribution of exposed Ru sites responsible for the high HDO activity of sulfur-doped Ru/TiO2 at a low reaction temperature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Ru-loaded titanium (IV) dioxide (Ru/DT-51, Ru/TiO2, Ru/TiO2(A)) Ru-loaded titanium (IV) dioxide (Ru/DT-51 and Ru/TiO2) catalysts were prepared via wetness impregnation method. Ruthenium (III) chloride hydrate (RuCl3 xH2O, 99.9% (PGM basis), Ru 38% min) was purchased from Alfa Aesar and used as an Ru precursor. DT-51, an anatase-phase titanium (IV) oxide with ∼1% of sulfur content was purchased from TRONOX. Pristine titanium (IV) oxide with a mixed phase of rutile and anatase (nanopowder, 21 nm primary particle size, ≥99.5% trace metals basis) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and denoted as TiO2. A pristine anatase phase titanium (IV) oxide (nanopowder, 99.7% metals basis, 15 nm APS Powder) was obtained from Alfa Aesar and denoted as TiO2(A). For each catalyst, RuCl3 xH2O was dissolved in 100 mL of deionized (DI) water and subsequently loaded into 2 g of supports via wetness impregnation method. The resulting mixture was vigorously stirred at an ambient temperature for 2 h, and the solvent was removed using vacuum evaporator with the bath temperature at 80 °C. The moist solid was dried overnight in an oven at 105 °C, followed by reduction under the flowing gas of 10% H2/N2 (total flow rate: 100 mL/min) at 300 °C for 3 h. The reduced catalysts were passivated with 5% O2/N2 at an ambient temperature for 30 min for the ease of storage and handling. The catalysts were denoted as Ru(5)/DT-51, Ru(5)/TiO2, and Ru(5)/TiO2(A), respectively. Typically, the amount of Ru loading was adjusted to 5 wt%. 2.1.2 Ru-loaded Al2O3 (Ru/Al2O3) Ru-loaded Al2O3 catalysts were prepared via a similar procedure with Ru-loaded TiO2 catalysts. Prior to Ru impregnation, boehmite (Sasol) was calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 6 h to obtain γ-Al2O3. Ru-loaded Al2O3 catalyst with Ru loading of 5 wt% was denoted as Ru(5)/Al2O3, while the catalyst with lower Ru loading of 0.5 wt% was denoted as Ru(0.5)/Al2O3. 2.1.3 Ru-loaded activated carbon (Ru/AC) Ru loaded on activated carbon with Ru loading of 5 wt% was purchased from Alfa Aesar. The moist catalyst was dried overnight in an oven at 105 °C and denoted as Ru(5)/AC. 2.1.4 S-doped Ru-loaded TiO2 (Ru(x)S(y)/TiO2) A series of sulfur-doped Ru-loaded TiO2 catalysts were prepared via co-impregnation method, followed by an identical procedure with Ru(5)/DT-51 catalyst. Ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4, Sigma-Aldrich, ACS reagent, ≥ 99.0%) and RuCl3 xH2O were used as the S and Ru precursors, respectively. A predetermined amount of S and Ru precursors (adjusted to the Ru amount of 5 wt%) were dissolved in 100 mL DI water and subsequently loaded into 2 g of TiO2 support using the wetness impregnation method. The resulting mixture was dried, reduced, passivated, and denoted as Ru(x)S(y)/TiO2 (x/y: molar ratio of Ru/S). 2.2 Catalyst characterization Ru dispersion of the catalysts was obtained by volumetric CO chemisorption (ASAP2020, Micrometrics). The catalysts were evacuated at 110 °C before the measurements to eliminate the physisorbed species, followed by the pretreatment with pure H2 at 300 °C for 120 min. The CO chemisorption was conducted at 35 °C over a pressure range of 50–450 mmHg. Ru dispersion was calculated using a stoichiometric factor of CO/Ru = 1. Carbon monoxide–diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (CO–DIRFT) spectra were obtained in a diffuse reflectance cell (Praying Mantis, Harrick) using a Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer (iS-50, Thermo Fisher Scientific) with a mercury cadmium telluride detector (32 scans, resolution of 4 cm-1). Prior to the collection of spectra, the sample was reduced under 10% H2/N2 at 300 °C for 30 min and cooled down to 35 °C under N2 flow. The spectra were collected after CO saturation by 1% CO/N2 flow for 90 min, followed by purging with N2 flow for 60 min Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the catalysts were obtained using JEM-ARM200F Cs corrected transmission electron microscope (Cs-TEM, Cold FEG, JEOL Ltd.) operated at 200 kV. Average Ru particle size and Ru particle size distributions were obtained by counting more than 200 metal particles per sample. Texture properties of the catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms obtained at 77 K (BELSORP-mini II, BEL Japan). All the catalysts were degassed at 200 °C for 3 h under vacuum conditions to eliminate impurities prior to the measurement. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller(BET) equation was used to calculate the specific surface area of the catalysts. An X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted on K-alpha (Thermo Scientific Inc., U.K.) spectrophotometer with a Kα-focused monochromatic source (1486.6 eV) equipped with a 180° double-focus hemispherical analyzer with a 128-channel detector. The binding energy was calibrated using the C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV. The data analysis was performed using the CasaXPS software after background subtraction using nonlinear Shirley functions. The deconvolution of Ru 3d peaks was conducted using the parameters described in the reference [27]. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the catalysts was obtained using a powder X-Ray Diffractometer (SmartLab, Rigaku) under 40 kV and 30 mA with a Cu-Kα radiation. Temperature-programmed-desorption of ammonia coupled with a mass spectrometer (NH3–TPD–MS) was performed on a BEL–CAT apparatus (BEL Japan Inc.) connected to a mass analyzer (HIDEN Analytical QGA) for an outlet gas analysis by using a secondary electron multiplier (SEM) detector. To quantify the amount of surface acid density, NH3 breakthrough curve was obtained at 100 °C on a BEL–CAT-II apparatus (BEL Japan Inc.). 2.3 Low-temperature catalytic hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol Low-temperature catalytic hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol was performed in a stainless-steel autoclave (5500 Compact Laboratory Reactor, Parr Instruments) with an inner volume of 100 mL, wherein guaiacol (2-methoxyphenol, Sigma-Aldrich, +98%) was used as a reactant. For a typical reaction procedure, guaiacol (2 mmol), DI water (20 mL), n-octane (10 mL, Alfa Aesar, +98%), and 0.1 g of catalysts were charged into the reactor. The air in the reactor was removed by flushing the reactor with H2 (three times by 10 bar H2), and the reactor was pressurized with H2 to targeted pressure. The reactor was heated in an electric furnace to the reaction temperature of 100 °C within 12 min. The reaction mixture was stirred by a mechanical impeller at 1000 rpm during the reaction. After the reaction proceeded for a certain period, the reactor was immediately quenched with ice-cold water to prevent further reaction. Anisole (Sigma-Aldrich, anhydrous, 99.7%), phenol (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥99%), methoxycyclohexane (Tokyo Chemical Industry, >98%), and cyclohexanol (Samchun, 98.0%) were also used as reactants instead of guaiacol. Product analysis was performed in each organic (n-octane) and water layer. Products were analyzed via gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS) equipped with a DB–5MS column (60 m x 0.25 mm×0.25 µm). The reaction products were quantified using a GC equipped with a DB-5 column (60 m x 0.25 mm×0.25 µm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). One milliliter of the aqueous phase product was extracted by 2 mL ethyl acetate before the analysis to prevent column damage. n-Nonane (20 μl, Alfa Aesar, 99%) was used as an internal standard to quantify the product yield, with the molar balance above 90%. The conversion of guaiacol, product yield, and the oxygen removal, representing the degree of deoxygenation, were calculated based on the following equations: Conversion mol % = 1 − number of moles of unreacted guaiacol initial number of moles of guaiacol 2 mmol × 100 % Product Yield mol % = number of moles of product ( mmol ) number of moles of reactant ( 2 mmol ) × 100 % Oxygen Removal % = 2 × Moles of 0 − Os + Moles of 1 − Os 2 × Moles of Guaiacol 2 mmol × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Low-temperature hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of guaiacol via Ru(5)/DT-51 catalyst 3.1.1 The effect of the catalyst support The HDO of phenolic bio-oil model compounds are typically conducted at high temperatures (typically above 200 °C) and high hydrogen pressure to achieve a desirable conversion and target product yield [6,8,10–13]. To alleviate the energy intensive reaction condition and investigate the active catalyst for the low-temperature HDO of bio-oil, a low-temperature HDO of guaiacol was performed at 100 °C and hydrogen pressure of 10 bar using Ru catalysts on various supports (Entry 1–4, Table 1). After conducting the reaction for 1 h, the conversion of guaiacol was 100% for the selected catalysts, and all of the detected products were aromatic ring saturated, obtaining methoxycyclohexanol (5), cyclohexanol (6), methoxycyclohexane (7), and cyclohexane (8). In most cases, methoxycyclohexanol was obtained with the highest selectivity, while cyclohexanol was also obtained with a relatively high selectivity. Since the main objective of HDO is to reduce the oxygen content, it is worth noting that obtaining high cyclohexane yield is desirable, which will result in high oxygen removal. Significantly high yield of cyclohexane was obtained when Ru was loaded on DT-51, compared to the Ru catalysts supported on other supports (TiO2, Al2O3, and AC), resulting in relatively high oxygen removal. When pristine TiO2, a phase mixture of anatase and rutile titanium (IV) oxide, was used as the support, considerably lower cyclohexane yield was obtained compared to DT-51, and the product distribution was similar to Ru(5)/Al2O3. When Ru was supported on activated carbon (Ru(5)/AC), the removal of the methoxy group less proceeded, obtaining relatively high methoxycyclohexanol and low cyclohexanol yields than metal oxide-loaded catalysts, thereby resulting in the lowest oxygen removal. In the case of Ru(5)/DT-51, the yields of cyclohexanol and methoxycyclohexane were similar to those for Ru(5)/TiO2 or Ru(5)/Al2O3; however, the product distribution differed significantly in terms of the high yield of completely deoxygenated cyclohexane, thus resulting in high oxygen removal. To elucidate the origin of the high oxygen removal ability of Ru(5)/DT-51 catalysts, a series of control experiments were conducted to confirm the conditions required to acquire high cyclohexane yield. Since DT-51 is a high-surface-area anatase TiO2 with ∼1% of sulfate species, there are three major possibilities that can affect the catalytic activity when Ru is supported on DT-51; increased dispersion of Ru due to its higher surface area compared to pristine TiO2, phase of the TiO2 (anatase), and existence of sulfur species. Initially, to confirm whether the dispersion of Ru affects the product distribution and the cyclohexane yield, low-temperature HDO of guaiacol were conducted through Ru(0.5)/TiO2 and Ru(0.5)/Al2O3 containing Ru loading of 0.5 wt%, as a control group of Ru(5)/TiO2 and Ru(5)/Al2O3. When volumetric CO chemisorption analysis of the synthesized catalysts was performed (Table S1), it was confirmed that catalysts with Ru loading of 0.5 wt% had significantly higher Ru dispersion than catalysts with Ru loading of 5 wt% (12% vs. ∼100% for TiO2 and 75% vs. 23% for Al2O3 loaded catalysts), with a substantially smaller particle size of Ru (9.3 nm vs. 1.2 nm for TiO2 and 1.8 nm vs. 5.7 nm for Al2O3 loaded catalysts), when the particle sizes were calculated based on the assumption of the hemispherical shape of Ru particles. It is noteworthy that particle size of Ru in Ru/TiO2 obtained from volumetric CO chemisorption (Table S1) might be distorted from the actual average particle size of Ru due to the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) between Ru and TiO2 [5]. When the HDO reaction was performed using Ru(0.5)/TiO2 and Ru(0.5)/Al2O3, considerably lower conversion of guaiacol was achieved at 1 h of reaction compared to the catalysts with Ru loading of 5 wt% (data not shown). To compare the product selectivity at comparable conversion with Entry 2 and 3, the reactions were conducted for 4 h using Ru(0.5)/TiO2 and Ru(0.5)/Al2O3 (Entry 5 and 6). Consequently, product distribution of Ru(0.5)/TiO2 resembled Ru(5)/TiO2, obtaining low cyclohexane (8) yield and oxygen removal compared to the case when Ru(5)/DT-51 was used. Moreover, no significant difference in the yield of cyclohexane and product distribution were found between Ru(0.5)/Al2O3 and Ru(5)/Al2O3, even though Ru(0.5)/Al2O3 had a significantly higher dispersion. Thus, it can be inferred that the sole effect of change in the particle size of Ru on the product distribution in low-temperature HDO of guaiacol is negligible. Subsequently, to determine the factors for obtaining high cyclohexane yield when Ru(5)/DT-51 was utilized, 0.1 g of Ru/Al2O3 and 0.1 g of DT-51 were separately introduced into the reaction mixture to adjust the amount of Ru and DT-51 with 0.1 g of Ru(5)/DT-51 (Entry 7). Consequently, product selectivity and oxygen removal similar to the case of Ru(5)/Al2O3 were obtained. Conclusively, the interaction between Ru and DT-51 resulting from the proximity of Ru and DT-51 during the catalyst preparation step was a crucial factor in obtaining high cyclohexane yield and oxygen removal in low-temperature guaiacol HDO. Compared to the pristine-phase-mixture titanium oxide(IV) (TiO2), DT-51 is a single-anatase-phase titanium(IV) oxide containing trace amount of sulfur species. Therefore, to verify whether the high cyclohexane yield in Ru(5)/DT-51 was attributed to the interaction between anatase-phase TiO2 and Ru or the presence of the trace amount of sulfur, a catalyst with Ru loaded on sulfur-free pristine anatase TiO2 (TiO2(A)) (Entry 8) and a catalyst with sulfur and Ru contents similar to Ru(5)/DT-51 was synthesized (Entry 9), and their catalytic activities were tested. For Ru(5)/TiO2(A), low cyclohexane yield and oxygen removal were obtained like Ru(5)/TiO2 (Entry 2), while sulfur-introduced Ru(5)S(1)/TiO2 showed relatively high cyclohexane yield and oxygen removal as in Ru(5)/DT-51. Therefore, it could be concluded that high oxygen removal ability of Ru(5)/DT-51 originated from the sulfur content in the DT-51. 3.1.2 Effect of hydrogen pressure and reaction time Since Ru(5)/DT-51 showed the highest oxygen removal among various Ru-supported catalysts, low-temperature HDO of guaiacol was conducted at various hydrogen pressures and reaction times using Ru(5)/DT-51 as a catalyst ( Table 2). Within the various reaction pathways of phenolic HDO, direct deoxygenation is preferred when the reaction is performed under high temperature and low hydrogen pressure, while hydrogenation of the aromatic ring is preferred at low temperature and high hydrogen pressure [28]. When the experiment was conducted for 1 h, 100% conversion was obtained in all hydrogen pressure ranges. As the hydrogen pressure decreased, the cyclohexane yield increased, while the yield of methoxycyclohexanol decreased, eventually yielding higher oxygen removal value. However, when the hydrogen pressure was below 5 bar, the portion of consumed hydrogen compared to the total hydrogen in the batch reactor became significant, which rendered conducting an isobaric experiment impossible. Therefore, the experiment was performed at a hydrogen pressure of 5 bar or higher. The explanation about the increased oxygen removal based on the decreased hydrogen pressure will be presented afterwards in the following section (Section 3.1.3). Interestingly, when the reaction time was increased from 1 to 4 h under 10 bar of hydrogen pressure, no additional deoxygenation of oxygenated aliphatic compounds (methoxycyclohexanol, cyclohexanol, and methoxycyclohexane) occurred, resulting in unchanged product distribution. From this, it can be thought that whether the catalyst was quickly deactivated within 1 h of reaction or under corresponding reaction conditions, oxygenated aliphatic products are the final product, which cannot be further deoxygenated using the Ru(5)/DT-51 catalyst. 3.1.3 Confirmation of low-temperature guaiacol HDO reaction pathway via Ru/DT-51 catalyst The HDO reaction was conducted via Ru(5)/DT-51 using various reaction intermediates as reactants ( Table 3) to identify why additional deoxygenation did not occur despite extending the reaction time (Entries 12 and 13 in Table 2). In addition to guaiacol, aromatic oxygenates, such as phenol and anisole and aliphatic oxygenates, such as cyclohexanol and methoxycyclohexane were used as reactants. When the reaction was performed under 10 bar hydrogen at 100 °C for 1 h, using aromatic oxygenates as reactants, cyclohexane, an oxygen-free cycloalkane, was detected. However, 0% conversion was obtained when aromatic ring saturated aliphatic oxygenates, such as cyclohexanol and methoxycyclohexane were used as reactants. Alternatively, within the complex reaction of guaiacol HDO, combined with aromatic ring hydrogenation and deoxygenation of oxygen functional groups, it can be concluded that once the aromatic ring hydrogenation occurs, additional deoxygenation reaction of oxygen functional groups in aliphatic oxygenates compounds cannot occur. Thus, the reaction pathway of low-temperature HDO of guaiacol using Ru(5)/DT-51 can be proposed as done in Scheme 1. The reason of obtaining decreased oxygen removal with increased hydrogen pressure in Entries 10 and 11 in Table 2 could be demonstrated through this reaction pathway. In the Ru-catalyzed HDO of guaiacol, the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring through H-addition occurs more selectively than the oxygen removal through the C–O bond cleavage at a higher hydrogen pressure [9]. Since the reaction rate of the deoxygenation of aliphatic oxygenates is negligible, higher selectivity of aromatic ring hydrogenation obtained at higher hydrogen pressures might result in low oxygen removal. Thus, it could be inferred that in the HDO reaction of guaiacol, where aromatic ring hydrogenation and deoxygenation occur competitively, deoxygenation should be preferred over the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring to obtain high oxygen removal. In other words, to obtain high oxygen removal, a catalyst that selectively delays the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring is required to suppress the production of aliphatic oxygenates, which cannot be further deoxygenated. Notably, while comparing the HDO of phenol and anisole, which are aromatic oxygenates containing hydroxyl and methoxy groups, a significantly higher yield of cyclohexane was obtained when anisole HDO was performed. Hence, it can be postulated that the methoxy group is relatively easily removed than the hydroxyl group in the HDO reaction of aromatic compounds using Ru(5)/DT-51, which agrees with the results from other studies [9,29]. 3.2 Low-temperature HDO of guaiacol via Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 catalysts 3.2.1 Effect of S/Ru ratio in low-temperature HDO of guaiacol Since it was confirmed that the presence of sulfur species in DT-51 enhanced the oxygen removal in guaiacol HDO, a series of Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 catalysts with different sulfur contents were synthesized to determine how sulfur doping affects the low-temperature HDO of guaiacol. Fig. 1 shows the conversion of guaiacol and oxygen removal with time when guaiacol HDO was conducted using the Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 catalyst. Sulfur-free Ru(5)/TiO2 and Ru(5)S(1)/TiO2 already demonstrated 100% conversion after only 0.5 h of the reaction time, while guaiacol conversion gradually decreased as the sulfur content increased. For Ru(5)S(5)/TiO2, the conversion was below 30% even after 20 h of reaction. Compared to Ru(5)/TiO2, higher oxygen removal was obtained when Ru(5)S(1)/TiO2 was utilized, although it can be seen that further deoxygenation of aliphatic oxygenates cannot proceed with Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 catalysts as occurred for Ru(5)/DT-51 under the corresponding reaction condition based on the fact that the product distribution and the oxygen removal remained constant despite increasing the reaction time. Until the reaction time of 1 h, oxygen removal by Ru(5)S(2)/TiO2 was below that by Ru(5)S(1)/TiO2, which was attributed to the lower conversion for Ru(5)S(2)/TiO2. However, oxygen removal increased with the reaction time due to the additional deoxygenation of unconverted guaiacol, phenol, and anisole (also denoted as aromatic oxygenates). Eventually, 50% oxygen removal was obtained by Ru(5)S(2)/TiO2 as a result of the reaction of 4 h when 100% guaiacol conversion was obtained. For the case of Ru(5)S(5)/TiO2 with a higher sulfur content, oxygen removal was also significantly low due to low conversion. To summarize, conversion of guaiacol decreased with higher sulfur loading, but the oxygen removal obtained at 100% conversion was enhanced with sulfur addition. 3.2.2 Catalyst characterization of Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 catalysts A series of catalyst characterization were performed to determine the cause of the change in the catalytic activity in guaiacol HDO occurring at low temperature when sulfur was introduced to Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 catalysts. Fig. 2 shows the TEM images and Ru particle size distribution of Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 catalysts. As the loading of sulfur increased, the average particle size of Ru slightly increased from 3.6 nm for sulfur-free Ru(5)/TiO2 to 4.2 nm for Ru(5)S(5)/TiO2. Table 4 shows the atomic content of Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 and Ru(5)/DT-51 catalysts obtained from ICP–AES. As intended in the preparation, the Ru content was obtained near 5 wt%, and sulfur content increased as the impregnated amount of sulfur precursor increased. For the Ru-loaded DT-51 catalyst, sulfur content was larger than that in Ru(5)S(1)/TiO2 and less than that in Ru(5)S(2)/TiO2. However, the molar ratio of S/Ru obtained from ICP–AES was significantly lower than the intended values for Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 catalysts (0.2, 0.4, and 1 for y = 1, 2, and 5, respectively), implying that a certain amount of impregnated sulfur species disappeared during synthesis procedure. The loss of sulfur content was presumably attributed to the decomposition of ammonium sulfate precursor in the gaseous form during the thermal reduction process of the catalysts at 300 °C. Although the amount of residual sulfur was lower than intended, substantial sulfur remained as the added amount of sulfur precursor increased. To further investigate the reduction and loss of sulfur species during thermal reduction, the H2–TPR–MS analysis of Ru(5)/TiO2 and Ru(5)S(5)/TiO2 was conducted before the thermal reduction step (Fig. S1). As for the sample used in the H2–TPR–MS analysis, pre-determined amounts of Ru and S precursors were loaded on TiO2 via wetness impregnation, followed by overnight drying at 105 °C in a convection oven. Although the quantitative value could not be obtained due to the absence of the calibration process of an MS detector, the amount of hydrogen (m/z = 2) consumption was elevated with the introduction of sulfur, accompanied by the shift in the peak hydrogen consumption toward a higher temperature, which could be presumably explained by the restrained H2 activation ability of Ru originated from the interaction between sulfur species (Fig. S1 (a)). Since the hydrogen consumption increased after the impregnation of sulfate precursor, the reduction of sulfate species by H2 presumably occurred in addition to the reduction of ruthenium species. In addition, when the MS profiles of sulfur-related species were observed in the TPR procedure of Ru(5)S(5)/TiO2 before reduction (Fig. S1 (b)), SO2 (m/z = 64) and H2S (m/z = 34) were detected below and above 300 °C, respectively. H2S detection over 300 °C indicates that the reduction of sulfate species occurred around 300 °C or below. Moreover, from the detection of SO2 and H2S, a certain amount of sulfur removal in the form of SO2 or H2S was confirmed during the thermal reduction process, resulting in the lower amount of residual sulfur than the intended value. The change in the atomic content with the introduction of different amounts of sulfur could be confirmed through the XPS analysis. By confirming the surface atomic contents of Ru and S through XPS, a substantially higher value was obtained compared to the total atomic content obtained through ICP–AES, probably explained by the non-porous structure of the TiO2 support. Notably, the surface atomic ratio of S/Ru obtained from XPS was larger than the total atomic ratio of S/Ru obtained from ICP–AES, indicating that the introduced S was preferentially exposed to the catalyst surface than Ru. Exposed Ru site of Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 catalysts were quantified from the adsorbed amount of CO, as determined by volumetric CO chemisorption. Lower amount of CO was adsorbed on the catalysts as the loaded amount of S increased, implying that number of exposed Ru sites decreased with the introduction of S. Therefore, it could be postulated that reduced amount of exposed Ru sites, which are active sites for HDO, could be a possible reason for the lower conversion of guaiacol at Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 with a higher S loading. Especially, this decrease in the number of exposed Ru sites is thought to be a major reason for the substantially low conversion obtained from Ru(5)S(5)/TiO2 compared to other catalysts (including Ru(5)S(2)/TiO2). For Ru(5)/DT-51 (although it contains sulfur) the adsorbed amount of CO was similar to that of sulfur-free Ru(5)/TiO2, possibly due to the formation of smaller Ru particles owing to the higher surface area of Ru(5)/DT-51 (76 m2/g for Ru(5)/DT-51 and 54 m2/g for Ru(5)/TiO2). From the XRD patterns of the catalysts (Fig. S2), peaks corresponding to metallic Ru were not observed in all catalysts, while only clear diffraction peaks related to rutile- and anatase-phase TiO2 were observed. Thus, it can be inferred that Ru exists as small nanoparticles with sizes below the detection limit of XRD. 3.2.3 Effect of sulfur introduction on the Ru states in Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 The introduction of S can lead to two major changes in the properties of the catalyst; one is a change in the Ru state owing to the interaction between S and Ru and the other is a change in the surface acidity of the catalyst. In order to determine the cause of enhanced oxygen removal ability of the catalyst with the increased amount of the introduced S, the modified state of Ru, an active site for HDO, was confirmed through the CO–DRIFT analysis ( Fig. 3 (a)). CO adsorbed on the metallic Ru shows three major peaks depending on the exposed Ru species [30]; CO adsorbed on multi-carbonyl Ru species (Ru–(CO)3 and Ru–(CO)2) observed at 2141 and 2084 cm-1 and linearly bound Ru–CO carbonyl observed at 2020 cm-1 [31]. As can be confirmed from CO chemisorption (Table 4), the adsorbed amount of CO decreases with the increasing S content in the catalysts, which resulted in a significantly decreased peak intensity of adsorbed CO in the CO–DRIFT spectra of S-doped catalysts. In addition to the decreased peak intensity with increased S loading, relative peak intensity of multi-carbonyl Ru species gradually deflated compared to the peak related to linearly bound Ru–CO, implying that the ratio of Ru sites capable of adsorbing multi-carbonyl decreased compared to the Ru sites adsorbing CO linearly. Therefore, it can be postulated that the distribution of exposed Ru species altered with the introduction of S, and specific Ru species were covered with sulfur species. Fig. 3 (b) shows the S 2p XPS spectra of Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 catalysts. When S was introduced, peaks corresponding to sulfate were observed from 168.5 to 168.0 eV. Notably, as the S loading increased, the intensity of the peak corresponding to the metal-interacting sulfide species observed from 163.0 to 162.0 eV increased gradually [32]. Fig. 3 (c) shows the deconvolution results and peak positions of Ru 3d XPS spectra of Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 catalysts. According to the introduction of S, negligible change of peak position was observed for Ru0 3d 5/2, while binding energy corresponding to Ruδ+ 3d 5/2 gradually shifted to the lower binding energy with the increased loading of S. A decrease in binding energy of Ru with the doping of S implies increase in the electron density of Ruδ+ with the elevated S loading, which is originated from the intimate interaction between S and specific Ru species [23]. Combined with the results obtained from CO–DRIFT, it could be also confirmed that the introduced S interacted with Ru and altered the distribution of exposed Ru species by selectively covering specific Ru sites through the formation of sulfide species. Modification in the distribution of the exposed Ru species could also be confirmed through the NH3–TPD–MS analysis. Generally, NH3–TPD combined with a TCD detector is applied to evaluate the quantity and strength of surface acid sites of heterogeneous catalysts. However, since Ru-based catalysts are highly active in NH3 decomposition, adsorbed NH3 may decompose during the TPD sequence, necessitating the usage of an MS detector rather than a TCD detector. Fig. 4 shows the identified hydrogen (m/z = 2), ammonia (m/z = 16), and nitrogen (m/z = 28) through the NH3–TPD–MS analysis of the Ru(5)S(y)/TiO2 catalysts. The desorption peak of ammonia (m/z = 16) slightly shifted to a higher temperature as the introduced amount of S increased, but the degree of temperature shifts and the difference in the desorbed amount of ammonia were not as prominent as the differences in the activity within the catalysts. In contrast, the desorbed amounts of hydrogen and nitrogen, originating from the decomposition of adsorbed ammonia significantly decreased with increased S loading. It is well defined that ammonia decomposition using Ru-based catalysts occurs at a specific site of Ru (Ru(0001) surface uniquely arranged in five Ru atoms, also known as the B5 sites) [33]. Since the decomposition of adsorbed ammonia was significantly suppressed as the S loading increased, it can be deduced that introduction of sulfur species altered the distribution of exposed Ru sites toward inhibiting the exposure of the Ru B5 site, which is an active site for ammonia decomposition. Combined with the results obtained through CO–DRIFT and XPS analyses, it is reaffirmed that the introduced sulfur certainly interacted with Ru, and through this, the distribution of exposed Ru sites was significantly modified. Thus, it can be postulated that the catalytic activity of sulfur-doped Ru/TiO2 catalysts in the low-temperature hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol could be remarkably altered through the modification of the distribution of exposed Ru species via the introduction of sulfur species. The modified distribution of exposed Ru species in addition to the increased electron density of Ru (Fig. 3 (c)) which was attributed to the interaction with Ru and introduced sulfur might change the adsorption behavior of guaiacol on the catalyst surface which might be a one of the crucial factor that altered the selectivity and conversion of the sulfur doped catalysts [23]. In addition to the change in the distribution of exposed Ru species, the change in the surface acidity of the catalysts could also be responsible for the enhanced HDO activity of the sulfur-doped catalysts. To evaluate whether the introduction of S changed the surface acidic density of the catalysts, the amount of adsorbed NH3 was quantified through the NH3 breakthrough curve. As mentioned above in the NH3–TPD–MS analysis, Ru-based catalysts could decompose adsorbed NH3 into nitrogen and hydrogen, which obstruct the quantification of acid sites via NH3–TPD. Thus, the surface acid density of the catalysts was quantified by flowing 5000 ppm of NH3 followed by He purge at the isothermal condition of 100 °C ( Fig. 5), where the HDO reaction was conducted; additionally, the decomposition of NH3 did not occur (Fig. 4). Consequently, negligible change in the acidic density was observed despite the introduction of S. Therefore, it could be considered that the enhanced oxygen removal of S-doped catalysts was not attributed to the increased acidic density of the catalysts. To sum up, through CO–DRIFT, volumetric CO chemisorption, XPS, and NH3–TPD–MS analyses, it was confirmed that the introduced sulfur selectively covered the specific Ru site, resulting in the modification of the distribution of exposed Ru species. In contrast, a change in the acidic density of the catalysts due to the introduction of S species has not been identified. Thus, it can be concluded that decrease in the guaiacol conversion and enhancement of the oxygen removal ability obtained at 100% conversion with the introduction of S yielded changes in the distribution of exposed Ru species originating from the interaction between S and specific Ru sites. 3.2.4 Reusability of S-doped Ru/TiO2 catalyst To confirm the reusability of the catalysts, Ru(5)S(2)/TiO2, which showed highest oxygen removal after 4 h of reaction, was recovered by washing with 4 L of DI water and 500 mL of acetone. The recovered catalyst was regenerated by the reduction procedure performed at 300 °C for 1 h, and the catalytic activity of the regenerated catalyst was examined under the same reaction conditions (at 100 °C for 4 h) (Fig. S3). Consequently, significantly decreased oxygen removal and cyclohexane yield were obtained when Ru(5)S(2)/TiO2 was recycled, where product distributions similar to that of Ru(5)S(1)/TiO2 were observed, indicating that Ru(5)S(2)/TiO2 shows poor reusability. Therefore, ICP–AES and volumetric CO chemisorption of the catalyst after reaction were conducted to identify the cause of catalyst deactivation (Table S2). Consequently, a lower sulfur content than the fresh catalyst was obtained in the catalyst after the reaction, while noticeable structure modification was not observed after the reaction (Fig. S4 and Table S2). Furthermore, the adsorbed amount of CO in the recovered catalyst increased, implying that more Ru sites were exposed from the leaching of sulfur after the reaction. Thus, it can be concluded that leaching of the sulfur species critically contributes to the deactivation of sulfur-doped Ru/TiO2 catalyst, resulting in the reduced oxygen removal ability of the fresh catalyst, thus arising the need for further research on the catalysts with improved reusability by suppressing the leaching of active sites. Although the Ru(5)S(2)/TiO2 catalyst has a downside of inferior reusability, substantial improvement of catalytic activity in guaiacol HDO even at a low temperature of 100 °C could be achieved via the introduction of sulfur into Ru/TiO2 catalysts. 4 Conclusion In this study, various Ru-loaded catalysts were investigated in the HDO of guaiacol conducted at a low temperature (100 °C). Among the various supports applied in the study, sulfate-containing commercial anatase TiO2 (DT-51) showed a superior low-temperature deoxygenation ability, and its pronounced activity appeared at a low temperature was attributed to the sulfur content. To elucidate the effect of S doping in Ru/TiO2, S-doped Ru/TiO2 catalysts with various S/Ru ratios were synthesized, and it was confirmed that oxygen removal obtained at 100% conversion gradually increased with the increased S loading, although the conversion obtained at an identical time was sacrificed. Maximum oxygen removal of 50% was obtained at 4 h of reaction time for Ru(5)S(2)/TiO2. Through various catalyst characterization techniques, such as XPS, CO chemisorption, CO–DRIFT, and NH3–TPD–MS, it was confirmed that surface of Ru was partially covered by sulfur doping, and the distribution of exposed Ru species was modified via sulfur loading. Although the reusability of the catalyst was not ensured due to the leaching of sulfur during the reaction, which necessitates further research to increase the reusability of the catalysts, it was possible to significantly improve the HDO activity of Ru/TiO2 at low temperatures via the introduction of sulfur. coredata.dc:description: Hydrodeoxygenation of bio-oil to obtain oxygen-free hydrocarbon at low-temperature remains a substantial challenge to produce economically feasible biomass-derived fuel. Among the various Ru-loaded catalysts, Ru/DT-51, a sulfate-containing anatase TiO2, showed prominent oxygen removal attributed to the sulfur content of the catalysts. The introduction of sulfur on Ru/TiO2 resulted in lower conversion of guaiacol, although the degree of oxygen removal obtained at 100% conversion was significantly enhanced, with 50% even at mild reaction temperature of 100 °C. The introduction of sulfur modified the distribution of exposed Ru species by selectively covering Ru in the form of sulfide, which was confirmed through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), CO chemisorption, CO diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (CO-DRIFT), and temperature-programmed-desorption of ammonia coupled with a mass detector (NH3-TPD-MS). By introducing sulfur to Ru/TiO2, the product selectivity in guaiacol HDO was regulated to enhance the oxygen removal even at a low temperature of 100 °C.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced oxygen removal ability of sulfur-doped Ru/TiO2 catalyst in low-temperature hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol
